Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story: The latest issue of the law review journal sits on my desk, its crisp pages promising insights into new legal theories. As a judge, I know I must stay current, and I feel the weight of expectation—my rulings depend on my knowledge. Yet, as I reach for the journal, my phone buzzes with a reminder: the office function is this afternoon. I glance at my reflection, noting my modest attire, carefully chosen to align with my faith as a Muslim. The event will be filled with colleagues of all genders, and I sense the subtle pressure to blend in, to perhaps relax my dress code just this once. My mind races—should I spend the next hour immersed in legal scholarship, or should I focus on preparing for the function, maybe even reconsider my outfit to avoid standing out? The demands of my profession and my faith pull me in opposite directions, and I feel the tension rising within me, unsure which expectation I should honor first.
